item.title: Denmark Strait
item.description:
Ocean currents affecting the global climate are sustained by cold and dense water that sinks in the North Atlantic Ocean. A large portion of this water passes through Denmark Strait, the ocean channel located between Greenland and Iceland.

The amount of water entering the strait varies from day to day, and is controlled by ocean vortices. Knowing the mechanisms associated with these vortices is of key importance for understanding and predicting Earth’s climate. This figure shows vortices simulated using a high-resolution, realistic, general circulation model:

Several currents interact with each other and with the seafloor in Denmark Strait. We can disentangle different pathways by seeding and tracking virtual particles in our model. This animation shows how the temperature of water particles changes during their journey:
